ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NEW MEASURES TO STIMULATE ECONOMY


    1. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Finance if he will implement new measures to stimulate the economy.
TURMOIL IN INDONESIA
(Economic implications for Singapore)


    2. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Minister for Finance what are the economic implications for Singapore arising from the recent turmoil in Indonesia; in particular, whether growth this year is more likely to be in the lower half of the 2.5-4.5 per cent forecasted range and, if so, whether the Government will activate off-Budget measures to help firms and retrenched workers in financial difficulties.
REGIONAL ECONOMIC CRISIS
(Impact on Singapore economy)


    3. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Finance (a) what is the latest assessment on the adverse impact of the worsening economic and political situation in Indonesia and the prolonged adverse economic conditions of Japan and other Asian countries on the Singapore economy; (b) whether the possibility of a sudden economic downturn or recession is much more imminent now; and (c) whether there is now an urgency to respond to the worsening regional economic crisis with various off-Budget measures such as the

Column: 9

lowering of Government taxes and charges and the provision of stimulus in the form of substantial increases in infrastructure expenditure.

OFF-BUDGET MEASURES

(Introduction)


    4. Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed asked the Minister for Finance whether it is now time to introduce more off-Budget measures, in anticipation of the probable consequences of the economic crisis in Indonesia and its effect on Singapore's economy.

    5. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Finance, with further economic slowdown, what off-Budget measures will be implemented by the Government to boost the economy.
REGIONAL ECONOMIC CRISIS
(Measures to minimise possible fallout)


    6. Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed asked the Minister for Finance, in facing the regional economic crisis and the recession predicted in Japan, what are Singapore's immediate concerns and what measures the Government will take to minimise their possible fallout.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Questions 1 to 6 together as they are related?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Tay Beng Chuan and Dr Lee Tsao Yuan have asked about the impact of the recent developments in Indonesia on the Singapore economy. Mr Tay and Mr Zainul Abidin also wanted to know how the economic conditions of Japan and other Asian countries would affect Singapore. The effects of the financial turmoil and developments in Indonesia have yet to be fully played out. The current outlook for the external environment is therefore mixed. While the US and EU economic growth remains healthy, the Asian economies have come under severe downward pressure. In Japan, there are signs of a

Column: 10

substantial slowdown but it will be ameliorated to some extent by their recent fiscal stimulus package. The economic situation in Thailand and South Korea appears to have stabilised somewhat. But developments in Indonesia have increased volatility over the short-term. The overall picture is still one of uncertainty.

    Dr Lee has also asked about the specific impact of the financial turmoil on the economic forecast. MTI's GDP growth forecast of 2.5-4.5% for 1998 has factored in the regional financial turmoil, and its impact on the growth prospects of our neighbouring countries. But as developments, especially in Indonesia, have yet to stabilise, nobody can be certain about the full impact of the financial crisis on our economy at this point in time. However, as the Singapore economy is fairly well diversified, we are unlikely to slip into negative growth this year as growth will be supported by the relatively healthy performance in the US and EU economies.

    Mr Tay, Dr Lee, Mr Chng Hee Kok, Mr Zainul Abidin and Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon have all asked about the implementation of off-Budget measures. As I have mentioned during the Budget debate, the Government will implement further measures if economic growth slows down significantly. The Government is monitoring the economy very closely. In the first quarter of 1998, economic growth has slowed to 5.6%. Growth in the second quarter is expected to moderate further as impact from the regional financial turmoil filters through the economy. Non-oil domestic exports have declined by 1.6% in April. Preliminary data showed it continued to drop by 6% in May. We will soon know how sharply the second quarter GDP growth has declined. We will then decide if we should proceed with additional measures to help the economy.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, the Minister for Finance, in his answer, said that the Government will only consider implementing off-Budget measures if the economy slows down significantly. May I know from the Minister what does he mean by "significant slowdown"? What percentage is he looking at?

Column: 11



    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: A "significant slowdown" would mean that it would be down to negative growth, for example.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Is it for one quarter?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: The standard definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters of negative growth.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Sir, may I ask the Minister when will the second quarter results be known since the Minister did say that off-Budget measures will be decided only when the second quarter results are known?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: We will not know the full second quarter results until some time in July, but we do not expect to have to wait quite that long. I think by the middle of this month or towards the latter part of the month, we will know the full May results and that might give us sufficient indication of the forward trend. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence, Dr Tony Tan, already indicated that we might do something before the full second quarter results are known.

    Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed (Cheng San): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister whether the number of those retrenched would be considered as one of the significant factors before more off-Budget measures will be introduced?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Yes, of course, that would be a significant indication. In fact, that reflects the economy.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok (East Coast): Sir, will the Minister explain what is the time frame by which measures will be effective the moment they are implemented? In other words, how long will all these measures that he has in mind, if implemented, take effect?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: It depends on the nature of the measures. A rebate, for example, will take place immediately. Infrastructure spending will take some time to filter through, again, depending on the type of spending which takes place. A tax cut will not take place until next year. So there is a whole package of measures

Column: 12

we can consider, some of which are going to be effective immediately, and some are medium and longer term.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok: Taking into account the period when historical data is known and the measures which the Minister has taken into account in his basket of measures which he will implement when the economy slows down significantly, there will be a certain period of time for measures to take effect.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I am not quite sure what he means. But if we do something, for example - I am not promising this - towards the end of June or July, as I mentioned, if we announce the rebates they would take place immediately other than the time for processing. As for the other measures, it depends on the nature of the actual cuts and the programmes. So I cannot give him a precise figure. But I am sure the Member realises that we went through this experience in 1985/86 and it did not take us very long to recover although the circumstances, I would admit, between now and 1985/86 are completely different.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Sir, with regard to the impact of the recent turmoil in Indonesia, surely the Minister will agree that that impact would be negative in terms of the impact on the Singapore economy. To the extent that the growth forecast of 2.5-4.5% was made earlier on this year and the situation in Indonesia has since deteriorated, surely that would mean that the growth forecast for Singapore, even if it remains within 2.5-4.5%, would actually hover around the lower end of the range or that the forecast range would be lower than 2.5-4.5%. Would the Minister agree?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I cannot disagree with her arguments.

    Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed: Sir, since we have already got indications that the number of those to be retrenched would be more than the number retrenched in 1985 when we had very strong measures introduced, would it not be better to introduce the measures now rather than wait for the second quarter results where we may end up with a position of too little, too late?

Column: 13



    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: These are all estimates of what the retrenchments might be. I am not certain that in fact it will actually turn out to be more than in 1985/86. I think the most important thing to remember is that we should not over-react to monthly changes in statistics. We have to ensure that whatever measures we take are consistent with sound principles. The last thing we want to do is for the Government to micro-manage the economy, ie, when you see one sector falling, suddenly you have to apply measures to correct the whole economy. We will take whatever measure is necessary and I am not suggesting that we should wait months or years for something to happen. All indications are that it will be sooner than later.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, I want to ask the Minister about the growth forecast of 2.5-4.5%. We are looking at the weak regional growth now. Malaysia has announced a negative growth, so did Hong Kong. Thailand and Indonesia would not be much better. On that basis, how can we expect the Singapore economy to be on a positive note? If so, would he now implement the measures sooner than later?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Even if it should turn out to be at the lower end of our range, that is not a recession. By international standards, 2.5-3% is excellent performance. It is only when you look against the whole background of Singapore's growth of 7-8% in the past few years that you think it is a disaster. In fact, without the exceptional circumstances of the last few years, 7-8%, in Singapore's state of present GDP, is unsustainable. We have said this many times. In fact, our medium term forecast for non-inflationary growth is 4-6%.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, if you consider the business sector, it has actually gone into negative growth this year. If that is the case, would the Ministry look into some measures to be introduced as quickly as possible?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Which negative growth are you talking about?

Column: 14



    Mr Leong Horn Kee: GDP growth.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: No, we will not wait for GDP growth to go negative before we do something. If the trend is clearly going to head in that direction, we will try to do something. This is what we have assured the House.

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, in short, why are we not responding quickly?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I have just tried to explain why. We would like to look at the May figures before we react. Surely, it is not too long to wait for a few weeks.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister two questions? They are not related. First of all, the question of US$5 billion loan to Indonesia.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, your question is not related to the Question on the Order Paper. I will not allow you to ask that question. Could you ask questions related to the Question under discussion?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thought we were discussing the economy and I want to know whether the Government has considered reviewing its decision to grant the US$5 billion loan in view of the present situation in Indonesia. Is that not part of it?

    Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, there is a Question related to this topic later on in the Order Paper. Could you wait for that Question to be raised?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: All right, Sir. Then may I ask the Minister about the other question, and that is, the off-Budget measures. May I know whether there are any measures in the pipeline to protect the workers? Has the Government heard of reports that companies in Woodlands are getting rid of Singaporeans and taking on board Malaysians because they find them cheaper?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I suggest that when the Member hears of these rumours, please document them and we will look into them individually. As far as

Column: 15

Government's action to help the workers, it is going to be a comprehensive package, including what we have said before, that one of the most important things that we need to do is to ensure that our workers will be able to cope with new jobs. So training and retraining is going to be a major focus.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask the Minister whether the Government is monitoring retrenchment of workers by Singapore companies? Is the Government monitoring or just turning a blind eye?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I think that is a very silly question. Surely, you do not expect the Government to be so negligent as not to monitor unemployment.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Then tell us how you are monitoring it.

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Please address your question to the Minister for Manpower.

    Mr Lim Swee Say (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, may I ask the Minister for Finance, as and when off-Budget measures are introduced, besides addressing the issue of lowering the cost of doing business in Singapore and stimulating the economy through infrastructure projects, whether he will consider introducing some new measures to encourage companies to build new capabilities during this slowdown?

    Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: I am aware of the Member's sentiments. It has appeared in the press and we will certainly take it into consideration. I will discuss with my colleague.

Column: 15

JTC AND HDB RENTALS

(Rebates)


    7. Mr Ang Mong Seng asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether JTC and HDB will grant rebates on rentals to assist the small and medium industries and shop tenants during this period of economic slowdown.

Column: 16



    The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, in his Budget Speech, Minister for Finance announced that the Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) and the Housing and Development Board (HDB) would extend additional rental concessions to tenants and lessees as part of the Government's efforts to moderate cost pressures on businesses. Both JTC and HDB have frozen their posted rents of land leases until June next year. JTC has also frozen the posted rents of its factories during this period. In addition, JTC and HDB have moderated the annual rental adjustments of their industrial land and premises. About 70% of JTC lessees and 35% of HDB lessees who are paying at least 85% of market rent will not see any increase in their rents for the next 12 months. The remaining lessees who are paying rents that are well below market rates will have their rental adjustments capped at 4%. JTC's existing factory tenants will also be given a rebate of up to half of their contracted rent adjustment.

    In October 1996 and December 1997, HDB implemented a package of rental concessions for its industrial and commercial tenants. This included moderating rental adjustments at third renewal of tenancies, granting up to 10% rental concession for those paying above market rent, and staggering increases in rent for subletting and assignment cases. About 10,000 commercial and industrial tenants (which are almost 50% of HDB's tenants) have benefited from the rental adjustment policy to-date. The total impact of HDB's measures was revenue forgone of $220 million. JTC and HDB will pass on to tenants the full 15% property tax rebate announced during this year's Budget Statement. They will also make upfront collections of rental payments monthly rather than quarterly.

    The Government will continue to monitor economic conditions closely and take further measures, if necessary, to moderate cost pressure on businesses.

Column: 17

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD SHOPS
(Lowering of rentals)

    8. To ask the Minister for National Development, as the economic downturn has severely affected the business of shopkeepers in Housing and Development Board estates, whether he will consider lowering the rental charges for shops.

HDB will continue to monitor the situation closely and, if the need arises, introduce additional measures to assist its tenants.

    12. Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin asked the Prime Minister whether, in view of the latest political and economic situation in Indonesia and the assessment that Indonesia may not be able to meet its sovereign obligations, the Singapore Government will review its $5 billion loan to Indonesia.
UNREST IN INDONESIA

UNREST IN INDONESIA
(Humanitarian assistance)


    14. Mr Zulkifli bin Baharudin asked the Prime Minister whether, in view of the deteriorating situation in Indonesia, it is timely for Singapore to consider humanitarian assistance to Indonesia.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, and on behalf of the Prime Minister, I will answer Questions 9 to 14 together as they are related.

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Political change in Indonesia has taken place peacefully and constitutionally. Political and social unrest has abated. Nevertheless, the new Indonesian government under President Habibie faces formidable challenges. The Indonesian economy has been badly damaged. The rupiah remains weak. Trade financing for Indonesian exports and imports has practically stopped. Corporate debt restructuring negotiation is not yet completed. Unemployment is growing. Prices are rising sharply, including prices of necessities.

Column: 19



    Indonesia's changed political and economic situation does not affect our commitment to implement practical schemes to help Indonesia. We will proceed with our proposed bilateral trade finance guarantee scheme and humanitarian assistance.

    The Prime Minister has already given the details of the Bilateral Trade Finance Guarantee (BTFG) scheme to the House on 20th April this year.

    The BTFG will initially provide export credit insurance for Singapore's domestic exports to Indonesia. Later, after we have gained some experience with the scheme, it can be expanded to cover retained imports from Indonesia and also exports to Indonesia through Singapore by countries which do not have their own bilateral export credit schemes. The scheme will be operated by ECICS Limited using Singapore-based banks and designated trade finance banks in Indonesia.

    Singapore and Indonesian officials met on 20th April to discuss the scheme. After the first meeting, the Indonesian officials stated that they would need to study the scheme further.     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time.

    Sir, since the last amendments to the Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA) in 1993, both the global and local drug situations have changed significantly. Further amendments to the MDA are now necessary so that we can continue to effectively curb drug abuse and drug trafficking in Singapore.

"Ice" and "Ecstasy"

    Firstly, psychotropic drugs are increasingly emerging as a major global threat. The UN International Drug Control Programme has reported that synthetic and psychotropic drugs will be a problem of global concern in the 21st century. Psychotropic drugs are synthetic substances made entirely from chemicals. They act on the central nervous system and have mind-altering effects which can have stimulating, tranquillising or hallucinating effects. Besides inducing adverse changes in behaviour, these drugs can also have extremely harmful effects on the body.

    "Ice" and "Ecstasy" are examples of psychotropic drugs. These drugs are easy to produce and can be manufactured from easily obtainable chemicals and raw materials in makeshift laboratories. I am told that "Ice", for example, can be produced using ephedrine, several washtubs and a stove. "Ecstasy" causes hallucinations, anxiety and can cause death by overheating of the body or dehydration. "Ice" is even more harmful and lethal. It is known to cause severe convulsions, hallucinations, liver and kidney damage, cardiac damage, stroke and death. "Ice" abusers are also prone to violent behaviour after abusing it. Although not yet rampantly abused in Singapore, "Ice" currently poses a major threat due to its widespread and growing popularity in the region.

Column: 41



    In Singapore, no "Ecstasy" abuser was arrested in 1995. But in 1996, 661 were arrested. The number fell to 403 in 1997 after intensive CNB enforcement. In 1995, no "Ecstasy" was seized. But in 1996, almost 39,000 were seized, and in 1997, almost 55,000 "Ecstasy" pills were seized.

    No "Ice" abuser was arrested in 1995 also. But 5 were arrested in 1996 and 82 in 1997. There has also been an increase in "Ice" trafficking activities in Singapore. In 1995, 12.3 grammes were seized and in 1996, 0.69 grammes were seized. But in 1997, 90.3 grammes were seized. But in the first four months of this year, we have already seized about 560 grammes of "Ice", due to the success of major CNB operations like Operation Phantom.

Enhanced Penalties for "Ice" and "Ecstasy" Traffickers

    Although the "Ecstasy" abuse situation today is under control, we must act decisively to ensure that it does not gain a foothold in Singapore. Stricter legislation against traffickers of "Ecstasy" and "Ice" will also deter international syndicates from using Singapore as a transhipment point for these drugs.

    My Ministry proposes that the Act be amended to facilitate the prosecution of "Ice" and "Ecstasy" traffickers. Clause 7 of the Bill amends section 17 of the Act to extend the presumption clause for trafficking to include "Ice" and "Ecstasy". A person caught in possession of more than 25 grammes of "Ice" or 10 grammes of "Ecstasy" is presumed to be trafficking in these drugs and would be charged with the offence of trafficking Thus the burden of proof against trafficking would rightly be placed on the offender. These amounts, ie, 25 grammes of "Ice" and 10 grammes of "Ecstasy" are equivalent to 100 doses of the estimated daily consumption of these drugs. This is the same basis for deriving the presumption amounts for other drugs such as heroin, opium, morphine and cocaine.

    In addition, clauses 21(a) to (c) of the Bill amend the Second Schedule of the MDA to make the death penalty mandatory for anyone who is convicted of trafficking,

Column: 42

manufacturing, importing or exporting more than 250 grammes of "Ice". This amount is equivalent to 1,000 doses of the daily estimated consumption of the drug. This is also the basis for deriving the amount attracting capital punishment for the other drugs which I mentioned. Unlike "Ice" which is extremely dangerous, "Ecstasy" is less potent and dangerous. Hence, MHA is not proposing at this stage to introduce the death penalty for "Ecstasy"-related offences. Nevertheless, the penalties are still heavy as "Ecstasy" is a Class A drug. For example, trafficking in "Ecstasy" currently attracts a maximum penalty of 20 years' imprisonment and 15 strokes of the cane, and a minimum penalty of 5 years' imprisonment and 5 strokes of the cane.

Hardcore Addicts

    Let me now turn to the next set of amendments, which are related to the proposed long-term imprisonment and caning for hardcore drug addicts.

    Sir, although the overall drug situation in Singapore has improved, the problem of a large number of hardcore addicts who repeatedly relapse still remains. A hardcore addict is one who has been admitted to DRC or Prison for a drug offence for more than two times. In fact, the proportion of hardcore addicts among our total DRC population has increased from 65% in 1994 to 71% in 1997.

    It is important that these hardcore drug addicts are not treated as victims. They are bad people. Firstly, to feed their expensive habit, many of them turn to crime. More than 73% of hardcore drug addicts have some form of criminal record, while about 76% of all addicts with criminal records are hardcore addicts. So, they are criminals also. Secondly, these hardcore addicts contaminate the innocent and lead them to experiment with, and consume drugs, thus perpetuating a drug culture. Every addict, especially a hardcore addict, is a potential pusher and trafficker. These hardcore addicts also inflict untold misery on their families and are a financial burden to their family members. They are bad role models, especially if they are fathers or mothers.

Column: 43



Long Term Imprisonment and Caning for Hardcore Addicts

    That is why the Act is amended to provide for long-term imprisonment and caning for hardcore addicts. This serves a number of objectives. Firstly, by putting these addicts out of circulation for a long time, it will help to protect the public from them, especially as the majority of these addicts turn to crime to feed their habit. Secondly, it is also aimed at deterring drug addicts from persisting in their drug addiction by making the consequences of continued addiction very severe. In the long run, the long-term imprisonment and caning should help to reduce the relapse rate of drug addicts and deter potential drug abusers from falling into the drug trap. Thirdly, it is to punish these recalcitrant addicts for persisting with their drug habit. Public reaction to my announcement that we would enhance punishment for hardcore addicts, has been positive.

    Clause 15 of the Bill will introduce a new section 33A in the MDA to provide for this new regime. Upon conviction in Court, hardcore addicts would be given a mandatory imprisonment term of between five and seven years and between three and six strokes of the cane under the first tier penalty. Under the second tier penalty, any addict who has been punished under the first tier penalty and who is arrested again for a drug consumption offence will, upon conviction, be punished with a longer imprisonment term of between 7 and 13 years, and between 6 and 12 strokes of the cane. For the purpose of prosecuting an addict under this new section, the Government will only rely on DRC admissions and drug conviction records on or after 1st October 1992.

    The current intention is to only target the long-term imprisonment regime and caning at hardcore abusers of opiate drugs, ie, heroin, opium and morphine. This is because among the various drugs of abuse, opiate drugs have the strongest physical and psychological hold over their users. Besides, these are the main drugs

Column: 44

abused in Singapore, with more than 75% of all addicts arrested each year since 1994 abusing these drugs. However, the Government will carefully monitor the situation and will not hesitate to impose similar measures against hardcore addicts of other drugs, such as "Ice", should the situation warrant it.

    A related amendment is to enhance the penalty for failing to provide urine specimen under section 31(2) to that of drug consumption. The former offence, ie, failure to provide urine sample, refers to instances where arrested addicts refuse to provide urine samples for testing purposes without reasonable excuse when asked to do so. This amendment is necessary. Otherwise, suspected drug addicts would rather refuse to provide a urine specimen and be only liable for a lesser penalty of a maximum $5000 fine under section 31(2), than be liable for the harsher penalties of drug consumption. Clause 21(f) would amend the Second Schedule of the Act to equate the penalty for the offence of failing to provide urine specimen with the penalty for drug consumption. For the same reason, clause 14 would amend section 33(3) to include a previous offence for failing to provide urine sample as a previous drug antecedent for the purpose of sentencing.

    Hence, the new regime of long-term imprisonment and caning will apply to addicts who are caught for the consumption of opiate drugs or fail to provide urine sample, and have, let me elaborate: (a) at least two previous DRC admissions for opiate abuse; or (b) at least two previous convictions for opiate abuse; or (c) at least two previous convictions for failure to provide a urine specimen; or (d) one previous DRC admission and one previous conviction for opiate abuse; or (e) one previous DRC admission and one previous conviction for failure to provide urine sample; or

(f) one previous conviction for opiate abuse and one previous conviction for failure to provide urine specimen.

    A previous conviction by a subordinate military court for the opiate abuse will also be considered as a previous conviction for purposes of sentencing.

Extra-Territorial Jurisdiction over Offence of Drug Consumption

    I now wish to turn to the issue of consumption of controlled drugs outside Singapore. Currently, only consumption of controlled drugs within Singapore is punishable under the MDA. The Central Narcotics Bureau cannot charge persons who abused drugs overseas, say, in Malaysia, Batam, Bintan or Karimun, or anywhere else, and tested positive for drugs upon their return at our immigration entry points.

    There has been a noticeable trend of Singaporeans consuming drugs overseas in recent years. In 1994, 1,402 persons tested positive for drug consumption at our checkpoints. In 1997, the figure was 1,768 persons or a 26% increase over the 1994 figure. With more Singaporeans travelling overseas, the easy access of drugs nearby in neighbouring countries and the proposed harsher penalties for hardcore addicts, it is prudent to plug this loophole. Otherwise, local addicts would intentionally make trips out of Singapore to neighbouring countries to get their fixes to avoid arrest and prosecution in Singapore, and to make a mockery of our drug laws. Clause 5 of the Amendment Bill would create a new section 8A to confer on our Courts the jurisdiction to try the offence of drug consumption overseas by a Singaporean citizen or Permanent Resident whose urine sample was found positive in Singapore and to deal with them as though the act of consumption was committed in Singapore.

1988 UN Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotics Drugs and Psychotropic Substances

    While we have taken firm and incisive actions against drug abuse and trafficking domestically, we remain committed to international efforts to stamp out the drug

Column: 46

problem. This is because drugs and the proceeds from drug-related activities are global problems that respect no borders.

    In this regard, Singapore is committed to tackling international drug trafficking, importing, exporting and manufacturing. It has acceded to the three United Nations drug abuse conventions: namely, the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, the 1971 Convention on Psychotropic Substances, and, late last year, the 1988 United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic In Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances.

    The 1988 UN Convention, or the Vienna Convention, as it is commonly known, is an international co-ordinated effort to make it mandatory for signatory states to criminalise drug-trafficking and its related activities, including money laundering and the use of precursor chemicals in manufacturing controlled drugs. We only formally acceded to it on 21st October 1997 because we wanted to first put in place the legal framework, which is necessary if we are to fully meet our obligations as a signatory state to the Convention.

    Clauses 6 and 21 of the Bill would amend the MDA to allow Singapore to give effect to its obligations under the Vienna Convention. For example, we would criminalise the manufacture, possession and distribution of precursor chemicals, controlled materials and equipment intended for the manufacture of controlled drugs. The penalties would be a maximum of 20 years' imprisonment or $200,000 fine or both. A new section 18B of the MDA would empower the Minister to make regulations for various matters relating to the control of precursor chemicals, and controlled materials and equipment, such as the licensing of their import and export, and documentation requirements for their transhipment. A related amendment is clause 23 which amends the First Schedule of the Extradition Act to include offences relating to psychotropic substances and offences relating to benefits derived from drug trafficking as extraditable offences. The latter is one of the obligations of signatory states under the Vienna Convention.

Other Amendments

    In addition, the Amendment Bill also proposes various amendments that are essential to facilitate drug enforcement and to allow the Prisons Department and the Central Narcotics Bureau to operate more effectively. For example, clauses 8, 9, 13 and 18 of the Bill would strengthen the enforcement powers of CNB officers in relation to investigation, search and arrest of offenders under the MDA and its Regulations.

    Clause 12 of the Bill would provide for the mandatory forfeiture of any vehicle used in connection with an MDA offence. This is in line with similar provisions for the forfeiture of vehicles in other legislation such as the Road Traffic Act and the Immigration Act.

    Members may also recall last year's ruling by the Court of Appeal that "life imprisonment" should be equated to the natural life of a prisoner, rather than 20 years, as practised by the Prisons. Currently, some MDA offences attract a maximum imprisonment term of 30 years and 15 strokes of the cane. To uphold the original policy intention that the penalties for these offences should be more severe than life imprisonment, which was then taken to be 20 years, clause 20 of the Bill provides for "imprisonment for life" as an additional sentencing option for these offences.

Conclusion

    Sir, to conclude, the proposed amendments would allow my Ministry to respond effectively to the ever-changing drug situation and to sufficiently deter drug abuse and other drug related offences. The overall drug situation may be under control today, but we must never rest on our laurels. However, in addition to tough laws and strict enforcement, I wish to assure Members that my Ministry would continue to focus on preventive drug education, treatment, rehabilitation and aftercare of recovering addicts who are amenable to change. Only by adopting a comprehensive approach towards drugs would we eradicate the drug problem in Singapore.

As in the case of economics, I believe that such a disequilibrium situation is unhealthy and that steps should be taken to rectify the situation.

    Why has demand for public policy discourse increased? I can offer three reasons. The first reason is that our very economic success has satisfied our basic human needs and has engendered the desire for higher order needs, such as that for participation and belonging in society. Over the last 30 years, Singapore's GDP per capita has increased by more than eight-fold. This increase in real per capita income has enabled our material quality of life to improve by leaps and bounds. Home ownership, ownership of consumer durables, life expectancy, all of these have shown marked improvement. In short, our basic material needs are by now more than taken care of. A generation ago, our parents' prime concerns were mainly over making a decent living, owning a home, giving their children a good education.

    While these needs are still important today, economic success has added a new dimension to society's needs and aspirations. There are many in society who are no longer satisfied with the mere pursuit of material gains. They aspire towards something more and, that is, a sense of belonging in society. Part of that aspiration would include that of having a say in policy, particularly those policies which affect their lives as citizens of this country.

Column: 126



    The second reason is that our population, particularly the young, are now more highly educated. We have made significant strides in education since the 1970s. The entry ratio of polytechnic students increased from 2% in 1965 to 37% in 1995. Similarly, the entry ratio of university students increased from 4% to 20% during the same period. Therefore, we find that of those aged 15 to 39, 72% of the workforce now have secondary level education and above and soon 60% of those in their 20s would have tertiary level education.

    The third reason is that globalisation, including access to information via the Internet, has created greater awareness of the larger socio-political environment internationally, regionally and domestically. As a result of these three factors, there are more and more in Singapore society today who are interested in public policy, have an opinion on these issues and want to have a say. They may not necessarily be interested in joining a political party per se. But they hold the view that, as citizens of Singapore, they should be concerned and that this concern should be expressed by speaking up on public policy issues. Some of these views may be frivolous, some criticise for criticism's sake. But there are also some which are sincere and well-thought-through in their views. Although some in this group would insist that they are right and the Government is wrong, many would consider it sufficient that there be serious engagement. They wish that they be given the space to express their views, critical or complimentary, without fear of retribution that these views be heard, given due consideration and that the merits and demerits of these views be objectively and rationally debated in public, in the intellectual marketplace of ideas and may the best idea win.

    What about the supply of mechanism for public policy discourse? The number of channels has increased in recent years and more effective use has been made of them as well. These include the grassroots organisations, such as the RCs and CCCs under the People's Association, the recently expanded Feedback Unit, the Ministries' specific committees and

Column: 127

groups, formal and informal, established for the purpose of consultation and feedback. There are in addition other more general dialogue sessions, for example, the two recent occasions where the Prime Minister met young Singaporeans and professionals, respectively. In addition to the Government channels, there has also been more active use of the Forum page of The Straits Times as a channel for expression and feedback. And if I may say so, the Institute of Policy Studies, where I work, has, as its objectives, the twin role of furthering public policy discussion by means of research and conferences and being a bridge builder among the various sectors of Singapore society.

    How then do I know if there are now more channels for consultation and feedback if there is still an excess demand? I will be the first to admit that I have no statistics, no hard and fast evidence. But when one hears the dissatisfaction regarding the existing situation repeated over and over again, different forums by different people, then surely it amounts to more than just a passing fancy or a temporary phase. And if anything else, this dissatisfaction seems to have intensified and not diminished over the years. It would appear that this demand is strongest among the professionals and the younger generation. It may not be a major concern of the HDB heartlanders. But with education, this demand will strengthen and not diminish. All over Asia, economic well-being has led to the emergence of a middle class that is better educated, more socially and politically aware and more demanding of a voice in what affects them. There is no reason why Singapore should be so different.

    Parliament, mainly comprising the people's representatives, is the key institution for the conduct of public policy debate. In fact, this is already happening today. When the elected MPs speak, they often represent the views of their respective constituencies. However, there can be better use of Parliament as an institution for public debate on policy issues of current interest. In other words, in addition to passing legislation which is

Column: 128

in itself a primary responsibility of Parliament, it would be desirable for Parliament to be used even more as a major channel for policy discussion.

    Policy issues range from the strategic and national to the specific and municipal. I would like to see greater discussion of major policy changes in Parliament when they are announced. What is currently occurring is that Backbenchers use the Committee of Supply debates as the main occasion for bringing up issues under the specific Ministry cut. But why lump them all together at one sitting and not discuss these policies when they are hot off the press?

    A case in point is there are many changes in educational policy which have occurred in recent years. Many of these are not merely refinements of the system but represent systemic changes, indeed, a major rethinking of the very philosophy of education. One such example is the recent announcement on The Desired Outcomes of Education. At all stages of the educational system - tertiary, junior college, secondary, primary - this set of Desired Outcomes will be used to assess the performance of our formal education system. I would have liked to see this major policy change brought to the House for debate, not because I do not agree with The Desired Outcomes, in fact, I was glad to see the list, but because such a major policy deserves public airing and discussion. Such public discussion allows for good suggestions to be taken on board for future policy refinement, and concern and misconceptions to be clarified. One way in which this could be done would be for a motion to be moved, for example, "That the House endorses The Desired Outcomes of Education."

    My second and related proposal is that the Government Parliamentary Committees (GPCs) play a more active role in such public policy discussions. For example, the motion on The Desired Outcomes could be moved by a Member of the GPC for Education. In fact, the GPCs already are utilised to some extent in this manner. GPCs could be utilised to get the feedback on these major policy changes. These views could be aired in the House

Column: 129

during the policy debate. This is already the case, for example, during the Budget debate when the Members of the GPC for Finance and Trade and Industry bring to the attention of the House the feedback which they obtained from the business community. The system of debating major policy changes in the House has been done on occasions in the past. I recall that motions were moved in the case of the benchmarking of Ministerial salaries with the private sector in 1994 and for the second Cost Review Committee Report in 1996. However, what I would like to propose is that every major policy change be debated in the House and that the GPCs play an active role in this discussion by gathering feedback and moving the motion. If necessary, if it calls for a serious policy change in debate, a White Paper could be prepared, for example, in the case of the Ministerial salaries.

    Where specific and municipal policy issues are concerned, Question Time should suffice. However, the one hour allotted for Questions for Oral Answer is, in my opinion, too short for all such matters to be raised. The frustration that some Members experience is that there is insufficient time for all Questions to be answered as occurred today. There is of course the alternative of a Written Question. But an answer in written form does not permit the Member to seek further clarification on the spot and to wait for another month for further elaboration would really be too long a delay. My third proposal therefore is that Question Time be lengthened to 1� hours. One could argue that even this is insufficient. But a 50% increase is, in my view, a major improvement.

    There are two additional aspects of the public consultation process that I would like to discuss. The first is that we need to establish ground rules for this public discourse. I fully understand that elected Members will make statements with political objectives in mind. That is the essence of politics. But we should make every effort to debate in an objective and rational manner. At times, the debate can and should be robust, even heated. But such engagements should not be personal and should not be taken personally.

Column: 130



    The second aspect which I would like to discuss is public as opposed to private consultation and feedback. I believe that there is room for both. There are occasions when the Government would gather feedback on a private basis away from the public eye. This is particularly the case when providers of the feedback may not wish to be identified with the point made or that confidentiality of the policy is crucial, for example, in formulating the Budget. But public consultation and feedback is, I believe, becoming increasingly important. And it is in the latter case that Parliament can be more effectively used as a channel for such debate.

    I would now like to discuss briefly my views on the first part of the motion, that of a less adversarial Parliament. I do not believe that our present system is adversarial. I agree with the Member who spoke just now on this matter. If anything, apart from a few isolated incidents, Parliament is conducted in a very civil manner. The expression of differences of opinion should not, in my mind, be considered adversarial. Parliamentary debates should be encouraged to emphasise the objective to give all, and especially the best ideas, the opportunity to be heard. While I agree that I would not like to see a situation where there are fist-fights and hair-pulling in Parliament, I also do not envisage that this situation is likely to arise in this House in the near future. Hence, while I am fully supportive that the motion should be debated in the House and for which reason I have supported the motion to be debated, and I am also fully supportive of the second clause of the motion, I am unable to give my full support to the first clause regarding the less adversarial system of Parliament.

    In conclusion, allow me to reiterate my argument. The telescoping of the economic growth process in Singapore is unprecedented in world history. What took the developed countries 60 to 70 years to achieve, Singapore has achieved in 30 years, half that time. However, while the economic hardware and the material side have developed rapidly, the software, including social and political institutions, has been slower to evolve. As a result,

Column: 131

I believe that there is this disequilibrium situation of excess demand where public policy discussion is concerned and, hence, in this context, I believe that Parliament can be more effectively used as a major channel for such consultation and feedback.

Mr Rai rightly observed just now and he quoted examples of many other countries, particularly the ex-British colonies, which tried and failed. Indeed, many of these ex-colonies went through many constitutions since their independence, from a parliamentary system of government with a Prime Minister to a Presidential system, then military coup and perhaps a Presidential form of government, maybe another coup again, and so on and so forth. I think we can see quite a few of these examples in Africa, even today. And there is no end to the problem for them. But Singapore has succeeded so far because we are willing to adapt and evolve the system that we have inherited according to the changing social and political circumstances and according to the imperatives of our multi-racial, multi-lingual and multi-religious society.

    If we did not modify our electoral system, say, in 1988, today, we would not have GRCs and perhaps we would have an under representation of minority races in this Parliament. And if, in 1984, we had listened to Mr Jeyaretnam and agreed with him not to have the NCMP system, then we would not see Mr Jeyaretnam here today, and we would not have the NCMP system.

So we have the NCMP here today because I do not think you can find anywhere else in the world that an opposition, having contested in an election and lost, can find a place in Parliament to criticise the very party that it was opposing.

Indeed, I fully agree with her that there is some pressure in some quarters for more discourse on public policy and therefore more people may want to speak up. In my basic understanding of economics, I thought there is a way to clear the supply and demand, and that is the price mechanism. Perhaps in politics, some people may think that there is no price to be paid to be in Parliament. I think there is. If people are really keen on a public discourse in Parliament, then the price to be paid is to contest in the elections. Win the election, and then they can be in Parliament and, hopefully, contribute to the debates in this Parliament.

Column: 133



    If they do not want to, we have the NMP scheme and it has found a way for people, to contribute to public policy discourse in Parliament. But that does not mean that if other people want to make their views heard and do not want to be in Parliament, there is no place at all to make their views heard. There are many channels which I will elaborate. In fact, the two Members have talked about how people who want to comment on public policy could do so earlier on.

    So there is a price. In fact, there is even a price for the electorate for that matter. If the electorate really feels that there is a strong demand for some voices to be heard which will be a counter to what the Government would do or that Government policies were not to their liking, then the price they pay would be to vote in the opposition. Then they would have a new party, new government, and that is it. If they do not want to pay too much of a price, then they vote in some Opposition Members. But I think it is very difficult for the electorate to arrange for that. So, happily, the PAP has been elected time and again, because the people really want the PAP to be the government, although they do want some Opposition voices in Parliament. That is how Mr Jeyaretnam found his way into Parliament because of some unhappiness at that time in Anson, and we had Potong Pasir and subsequently at other places. And today, we are back to two elected Opposition Members. I think people knew what elected Opposition Members can really do in Parliament.

    Sir, Mr Rai rightly also observed that we have built up a political system that is honest and free from corruption. But I think we should not forget that this was not the situation that prevailed in Singapore in the 1950s or even up to the early 1960s. I remember, as a young boy, I followed my mother to the Siong Lim market in Jalan Besar. My mother used to tell me that if a hawker inspector in the 1950s needed food provisions, then all that person needed to do was to drive his car to the back lane of the market, leave his car unlocked and come back to find his car filled with provisions and his

marketing needs for the week. That was how it was. Corruption was rife from the top and all the way down to very junior officials.

And here in Singapore, we are lucky that we have worked at it and made sure that this system does not prevail and we must continue to work hard to preserve this value.

And that is the social ladder that we provide for all Singaporeans, ie, the equal opportunity that we provide in our system, and we have done that. We have seen many examples of people who have moved up from the lower rungs of society to high positions in Government or in the private sector. I think there are also many examples of these people in this House. So I think this system has worked and we must ensure that it continues to work.

    Mr Rai said that the younger generation of Singaporeans may want to emulate the Western style of democracy. Well, I have just recounted some examples of how some restless electorate wants to see an Opposition in Parliament. But I think

Column: 135

most Singaporeans are sensible. They are rational. They know what it is at stake and what is in their interest. And that is why even though they may want to have heated debates in this House, they know that they cannot just have people here who would criticise or make comments without really contributing to the formulation of good policies. They went there for an entertainment and at the end of the day, when they cast their vote, they know what is at stake when they give that vote to the person whom they voted for.

    That reminds me of another part of my young childhood. I used to enjoy going to the street corner and watch at the koyok man, the Chinese medicine man, showing off his skills like swallowing steel ball-bearings. Or he may have an iron rod to poke his neck until it bends, and he also carried a drum. At the end of the day, he would say, "This is my koyok. This is my medicine that can really make you feel good. And if something happens to you, this can be a palliative to your problems." I think many people went there for a good show, enjoyed it and some may sympathise with the guy because he would pass his hat round and they would just drop some coins in there. And some people actually bought that story and bought the koyok.

Column: 136

have opened up in the last many years to allow people to speak up and to contribute to our nation building, to contribute to our policy formulation and so on. Indeed, there have been many such mechanisms and channels and we can, of course, open up more if people want it. And the latest one is the S21 Committee in which two Members here are actively participating and others too have been asked whether they have views and whether there are people who may have views and who may be interested in taking part in the dialogues. And all these channels are outside Parliament and certainly people are most welcome to give all their views. During the 1985 recession, we formed an Economic Committee in 1986 to look into the measures that we needed to take and to devise a new economic strategy for Singapore, and many Singaporeans took part in it. Now, we also have a similar committee and again a lot of Singaporeans are involved. Similarly, the various committees and councils we have had in 1988, 1989, 1991, for example, to write up the Agenda for Action or The Next Lap or the various Advisory Councils' Reports on the Aged, on Youth, on Culture, etc, have involved lots and lots of Singaporeans. And those were not just reports studied and filed away, and left to dry on the shelf. They were reports prepared by earnest and serious people who had spent time and the Government had also spent a lot of time going through each of the recommendations. Eventually, when these recommendations were adopted, we spent money implementing them. I do not agree with Mr Rai when he said that we have been subjected to heavy criticisms from the Western press or media on our system of governance. I think not. Indeed, they have praised us, not that we need the praise or

Column: 137

we want the praise in order to do a good job. But people looked at our system when they came here, and they went away and say, "Yes, this is a serious place. This is a place where people make decisions based on rational arguments and they implement what they say." So they went away and said the system of governance here is correct and I think we should continue to uphold the system.

    Regardless of whether there is an opposition in Parliament or not, the PAP Government will continue to devise policies with the interest of the people at heart. It is not a question of staying in power. If it is so, we will not have devised the Elected President system, for example, to check our power. Where in the world can you find a ruling Government devising a system to check its own power? But we did it, because we believe that it is in the interest of Singaporeans that, who knows, some day a profligate government may be elected into power and it just squanders away all the hard earned reserves that we have accumulated over the years.     Mr Rai quoted the example of the judiciary system and asked us to take a leaf from it. He said that since the judiciary has evolved and been made less adversarial, it has been more consultative and it allows mediation and conciliation, and so on, Parliament should follow suit. I think there is a big difference between what the judiciary does and what Parliament does. What the judiciary does is that it settles disputes for parties. If there is no dispute between parties, then nobody needs to go to the courts. But because there is a dispute, whether it is a dispute between an individual and an individual, or an individual against a corporation, or a corporation against a corporation, or even a corporation against the Government, they need a third party to help settle the dispute. Before they eventually go to court, they get into a process of consultation, mediation or conciliation on the points that they agree, and the parts for which they cannot agree, the judge will listen to both sides of the story and eventually give his decision and verdict.

    But the role of Parliament and the role of the Government are very different. It is a not a question of dispute between the opposition and the PAP. It is a question of the Government setting out policies and implementing them, or the Government presenting Bills to be passed in Parliament into law and having a full debate of these, and eventually the legislature decides, "Yes, that is the kind of law we should have". Parliament votes on the Bills, and we implement them, and the court will then interpret those laws. At the end of the term, it is the people who will decide whether this Government has done well or not. It is not for Mr Speaker or Mr Deputy Speaker to say, "Good policy. I approve or disapprove, or I reject it, or this is my decision." No. It is for the people. The people will give that verdict. So it is very different from the judiciary and we therefore cannot emulate the judiciary in following a consultative, mediatory, conciliatory approach to our disputes. Because that is actually not a dispute between the Government and the opposition. It is a question of different policies which I will touch on afterwards.
